paperTitle: Dye-Sensitized Photoelectrosynthesis Cells for Benzyl Alcohol Oxidation Using a Zinc Porphyrin Sensitizer and TEMPO Catalyst

hasContent.text: Synthesis of porphyrin dyads HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO and hyd-ZnP-TEMPO. HO2C-ZnP-CO2H was initially synthesized, followed by amide coupling with NH2-TEMPO using HATU as a coupling reagent in dry DMF. For hyd-ZnP-TEMPO, the carboxylic acid group was converted into a hydroxamic acid using hydroxylamine hydrochloride (HCl·NH2OH) and DIPEA. Reference compounds HO2C-ZnP and hyd-ZnP were also prepared. Purification was done via silica gel column chromatography (CHCl3-EtOH) followed by precipitation in DCM/Pentane.

HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO was isolated as a purple solid (18 mg, 30% yield). Hydroxa-ZnP-TEMPO (hyd-ZnP-TEMPO) was isolated as a purple solid (16.3 mg, 80% yield). hyd-ZnP was isolated with 85% yield (15.2 mg). All structures were verified by 1H and 13C NMR and MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry.
UV-vis absorption and emission spectra were recorded in THF solution and on thin TiO2 nanocrystalline films (4 μm). Excitation for emission was performed at λexc = 430 nm or 556 nm.

All compounds exhibited classical porphyrin Soret bands at ~426 nm and Q-bands at 555-557 nm and 597-598 nm. E00 was determined to be 2.06 eV for all dyads. Table 1 shows λabs (ε/M-1 cm-1) for HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO: 426 (432.8), 557 (16.8), 598 (4.8). Emission peaks for dyads were observed at ~607 nm and 656 nm (Figures S1-S7).

The appended TEMPO moiety does not alter the absorption spectra of the ZnP subunits, indicating no significant electronic communication between ZnP and TEMPO through the saturated bridge. TEMPO does not quench the porphyrin singlet excited state as shown by no significant extinction of fluorescence in dyads compared to reference porphyrins.

Redox potentials were investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) after chemisorption on mesoporous indium tin oxide (meso-ITO) in acetonitrile containing 0.1 M LiClO4. Scan rate: 50 mV/s. All potentials are quoted relative to SCE.

Oxidation potentials EOx(TEMPO) were measured at 0.73 V (HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO) and 0.74 V (hyd-ZnP-TEMPO). EOx(ZnP) were 0.79 V and 0.84 V respectively. The Gibbs free energy of electron injection (ΔGinj) in TiO2 was calculated between -0.50 and -0.58 eV (Table 1, Figures S8-S10).

Zinc porphyrin oxidation occurs at about 100 mV higher potential than TEMPO, providing a modest but non-null driving force for the hole shift reaction from oxidized ZnP to TEMPO (ΔGhs = -0.06 to -0.1 eV).

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed on hyd-ZnP-TEMPO and models of ZnP/TEMPO using Gaussian 16 with PBE0 functional and 6-311G(d,p) basis set. Solvent effects (ACN) were accounted for using the PCM model.

Calculations confirmed that the unpaired electron is confined to TEMPO. Computed adiabatic ionization potentials (IPs) were 5.08 eV for ZnP and 5.21 eV for TEMPO, leading to a driving force for hole shift of -0.13 eV (Figures S11, S12).
Electronic transient absorption (TA) measurements. fs-ps TA performed with 550 nm excitation on TiO2 films in borate buffer. ns-μs TA performed with 532 nm or 355 nm excitation.

fs-ps TA spectra (Figure 2) showed an excited-state absorption (ESA) band at ~460 nm (S1 state of ZnP) and formation of ZnP radical cation (405-410 nm band). The rise of the cation band was fit with 6.3 and 75 ps time constants. ns-μs TA showed decay on multiple timescales (2 ns, 50 ns, 10 μs) (Figures 3, S13-S16).

The changes in TA spectra are consistent with the formation of the radical cation of the ZnP subunit upon charge injection into TiO2. Experiments with TEMPO in solution showed suppression of the ZnTPP cation band, proving the hole shift from ZnP to TEMPO is operative.

Photovoltaic performance in Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells (DSSCs). Fabricated with dyes on TiO2 electrodes using iodide/triiodide redox couple in acetonitrile. Measured under calibrated AM1.5 (100 mW/cm2) sunlight simulator.

HO2C-ZnP-TEMPO achieved Jsc = 4.3 ± 0.4 mA/cm2, Voc = 645 ± 10 mV, FF = 72 ± 2%, PCE = 2.00 ± 0.2%. hyd-ZnP-TEMPO achieved PCE = 1.65 ± 0.05%. Both dyads outperformed parent porphyrins lacking TEMPO (Table 2, Figures S17, S18).

The ZnP-TEMPO dyads show significantly higher Jsc and Voc than reference porphyrins, likely due to a longer-lived charge-separated state resulting from hole shift to TEMPO, which decreases recombination rate.

Photocatalytic para-methoxybenzyl alcohol oxidation in DSPECs. Tests conducted in 0.1 M borate buffer (pH 7.5-10) and acetonitrile + 0.1 M N-methyl-imidazole (Me-Imd). Dye loading estimated via desorption (Bu4NOH). Quantitative product analysis by gas chromatography (GC).

In borate buffer at pH 8, hyd-ZnP-TEMPO gave J ~ 200 μA/cm2, FE = 82%, TON = 26, TOF = 47 h-1. In ACN with Me-Imd, J ~ 100 μA/cm2, FE = 76%, TON = 13, TOF = 24 h-1. Dye loading was 84 ± 10 nmol/cm2 for hyd-ZnP-TEMPO (Tables 3, S1, Figures 4, 6, S19-S21).

Optimal pH for alcohol oxidation is 8. Photocurrent is significantly lower without alcohol, confirming TEMPO-mediated catalysis. Hydroxamic acid provides better anchor stability in acetonitrile, as the carboxylic acid dyad desorbed rapidly.
The TiO2-based DSPEC using ZnP-TEMPO dyads effectively catalyzes alcohol oxidation with higher performance than reported ruthenium-based systems.
Substrate scope testing using benzyl alcohol (Ph-CH2OH) and para-trifluoromethyl benzyl alcohol (CF3-Ph-CH2OH) at 50 mM concentration.
In borate buffer pH 8, CF3-Ph-CH2OH gave the highest photocurrent density of 0.50 ± 0.05 mA/cm2 compared to ~0.2 mA/cm2 for Ph-CH2OH and MeO-Ph-CH2OH (Table 4, Figure S22).
The higher photocurrent for CF3-Ph-CH2OH is attributed to its higher hydrophobicity, improving its affinity for the lipophilic environment of the porphyrin-TEMPO coated photoanode.
